name: Kheer
history: Kheer, also known as Payasam in South India, is an ancient Indian dessert, with references dating back to ancient texts. It is a staple in Indian cuisine and is often served during festivals and celebrations.
description: Kheer is a creamy and delicious rice pudding made with rice, milk, sugar, and flavored with cardamom, nuts, and raisins. It's a comforting dessert, loved for its simplicity and rich taste.

instructions.title: Rinse the Rice
instructions.description: Rinse the basmati rice under cold water until the water runs clear. Drain well.

instructions.title: Cook the Kheer
instructions.description: In a heavy-bottomed pot, combine the rinsed rice and milk. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer. Stir frequently to prevent sticking.

instructions.title: Add Flavorings
instructions.description: Once the rice is cooked and the milk has thickened, add sugar, crushed cardamom pods, raisins, and almonds. If using, add saffron strands for color and flavor.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Cook until the mixture reaches a creamy consistency. Remove from heat and let it cool slightly. Serve warm or chilled, garnished with additional nuts or dried fruits.

tips: Stirring constantly is key to preventing the rice from sticking to the bottom of the pot.
For a vegan version, substitute dairy milk with almond or coconut milk.
variations: Apple Kheer: Add grated apple during cooking for a fruity twist.
Chocolate Kheer: Stir in cocoa powder or melted chocolate for a chocolatey version.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 3 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container and refrigerate. Stir well before serving.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat gently on the stove or in the microwave, adding a little milk if needed to adjust consistency.
presentationTips: Serve in individual bowls garnished with a sprinkle of ground cardamom or saffron strands.
Garnish with a few almond slices and a mint leaf for a decorative touch.
